data.text: @karenvaites @SwedenTeam The #BranchCovidians will Never wake up. https://t.co/JUGepvdY0v

@karenvaites That tweet was loaded with condescension. You don’t get to tweet something rude and then complain about the replies. I knew those stats all along. My kids have been in school since August 2020. I drive on I-95 to take one. Tweeting rudely at worried parents doesn’t sway anyone.

@karenvaites @MartyMakary WE PUT SEAT BELTS ON THEM AND PUT THEM IN CAR SEATS.
MASKS ARE LIKE SEATBELTS.

@JustinLewis1977 @karenvaites And that still ignores the fact that 100% of kids have ridden in a vehicle in the last 2 years.  To determine the actual likelihood of dying in a car crash, you need to divide the number of fatalities by the number of rides they took

@JustinLewis1977 @karenvaites True, so it's weird that so many anti-mask and anti-mandate activists pretend that death is the only possible consequence of covid, ignoring the much greater likelyhood of infection.  Or, further spreading the virus to more vulnerable family members

@JustinLewis1977 @karenvaites But kids aren't exposed to covid every day, or even every week.  But the average covid infection is still more likely to kill or hospitalize a kid than the average car ride.

@smarzeli @karenvaites But even on this, the CDC estimates over half of all children HAVE been infected in the last 2 years, and there are still fewer COVID deaths in 2 years, with a > 50% infection rate than car deaths every year.

@smarzeli @karenvaites I don't think anyone is proposing intentionally infecting kids with COVID, anymore than anyone is proposing we intentionally wreck cars kids are in.

Part of the calculation of risk has to be the odds of the bad event ever occuring. Not just the odds of death in case of the event
